text:
Brown amber robe without foam.
Nose of coffee, smoke and a bit of hazelnut.
Light body with thin sparkling bubbles.
Finish is soft and a bit nutty.
Quite balanced and enjoyable, maybe a bit too watery for me.
Way more refined than the Rogue one, but the nut is also more discreet.
Bottle to cup. Dark brown, red tint. Chocolate aroma. Walnut, almond, bread.

Flaska från Martin Ficks. Djup, mahogny- färgad kropp med smutsgrå skumkrona. Doft av knäck, kakor och rostad malt. Krämig och halvsöt munkänsla. Smak av kakor, brända mandlar, mild choklad och jordig humle.
UPDATED: MAY 29, 2017 Bottle at unibar. Brown almost No head. Beige. Aroma: Caremel etc taste. A bit weak maybe its the style i dislike. Watery texture.
Clean mahogany color with a dense head of creamy sand colored foam. Light, dry and nutty with subtle roast.

Bottle, 1 pint 6 fl.oz. Home. A sparkling dark brown beer, red garnet hues with a medium beige foamy head ; medium retention. Dried fruits, candied fruits, caramel, roast, prune, chocolate notes. Light sweet, light to medium dry bitter refreshing. Medium good body, light creamy texture, average carbonation, fruity roasty dry finish. Overall, enjoyable, good !

Draft, chalice glass. Appears amber-brown with some lacing, and the nose is of creamy caramel malt. A very well-balanced brown ale. Its light-medium bodied, and has smooth caramel and mild, earthy hop flavor. Executed on point. Suitable for many settings.
Pours chestnut brown with a tan head. Smell is tea, nuts, caramel, old wood. Taste is sweet, lots of tea, a bit nutty, mostly hazelnut, caramel. Medium body. Mild carbonation. I liked it.

Color marrón, estilo azucar moreno, aparentemente turbio pero translúcido (y rojizo) si le da la luz, con capa de espuma de un blanco amarronado de dos dedos de grosor (no mucha retención). Repleta de sedimento. Carbonatación alta (sutil en boca). Textura oleosa. Aroma a malta, cacao, frutos secos (predomina la avellana, también algo de nuez). Sabor dulce, maltoso, con mucha presencia de cacao y frutos secos (avellana muy remarcada de nuevo, nuez también), con final terroso y ligeramente seco. En boca, entre trago y trago, queda cacao y mucho fruto seco. Nada nuevo bajo el sol teniendo en cuenta el estilo, pero qué delicia.

Preciosa en la Copa, de color azúcar caramelizado y espuma blanca. Notas a galleta, pan tostado, cacao, chocolate y frutos secos recién tostados. Quizá demasiado chocolate en nariz de inicio. En boca encontramos todo un despliegue de maltas, con toque a avellanas, cacao, frutos secos y final seco, terroso

Poured from bottle into a FW Brewhouse tumbler. Medium dark brown with reddish hue and a medium tan head. Roasty nose, a bit on the sweet side, raisin - like. Malty taste, a little sweet. Medium bodied with an oily texture. Overall a great brown ale, just hard to find my way.
Lovely dark and darker malts brew with decent complementary bitterness but not much hoppy aromas or flavor overwhelming. Liked texture and thickness of it and not loosing much drinkability.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2017 Nice slight malt with a touch of nutty scent. Great clear rich brown color. Taste was medium with malt and hop balance. Slight nuttiness, no cream, very clean. Easy to drink with a meal, but not a big sipping beer. Decent for a lower abv beverage. I have a feeling its better in bottle. Tap

12oz bottle. Pours brown with a tiny beige head. Aroma is very nutty with some toffee, brown sugar, toast, and a touch of chocolate. Taste is toffee, some chocolate, roast, light nuttiness (specifically almond), biscuit, grainy hops, and a bit of dark fruit. Dry finish with a little bit of yeast and some light grainy bitterness. Light-medium body. Medium carbonation. Smooth and creamy mouthfeel.
Half a 355ml bottle courtesy of Jasper. Pours red brown with a thin creamy head. Aroma of malt with nuts and cocoa. Dry finish with bitterness.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2017 Draft at Khyber Pass. Deep chestnut brown pour with a lasting foamy beige ring. Medium-dark roasted malts. Toffee. Smooth mocha coffee. Walnuts. Hazelnuts. Clean but not glossy. Simple but refined. Easy drinking. Nice take on the style.

Burnt Chocolate malt. Pours dark brown. Americans think this is English style ale ! I suppose it is if you like malty 'mild'. Really too sweet for me but its ok for a change. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nutty malty smells. Pours a deep clear brown with a small white very fast dissipating head. Only a little lacingTastes of caramel, malt and brown bread. Almost flat such little carbonation. An okay brown.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with slight ruby hue. Rich bready aroma with chocolate and toffee notes. Biscuit malt with toffee and swine chocolate notes followed by nuttiness and some subtle bitterness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Market Street Wine Shop, Downtown. Pours brown with a soft beige head. Aroma is cocoa, roasted nuts, sunflower seeds, caramel, and chocolate. Flavor is smooth caramel, lightly sweet, along with roasted nuts, salt, cocoa. Kinda has a brownie flavor. Quite tasty.
How: bottle Appearance: hazy brown, small offwhite head. Aroma: chocolate, some coffe, spice, brown sugar. Palate: light body, soft carbonation.

Bottle from World Beer Market (Sake no Taniguchi). Light coffee, cocoa, and nutty candy bar. Deep brown color, with mahogany on the edges, very pretty. Cocoa, ripe dark fruit, toffee, and piney hop. Light-medium body, very smooth. Delicious stuff, Very nice nose, too. A dull style tricked out in finery.

14/20 full taste, but of complexity to it, malty, no carbonation, bottled just over a year ago

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at the brewery. Pours a dark brown with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is cocoa and roast. Medium body, yeast. bread, light dry finish, good.

1pt 6fl oz bottle at home from FirmaBier. Nose is cocoa. Body is hazy brown, head is small, offwhite, creamy, mostly diminishing, good lacing. Aroma is chocolate, brownie, biscuits, raisin. Medium sweet, medium better. Finish is medium lasting roasty medium to heavy bitter. Medium body, slick texture, average carbonation. Easy dessert beer, simple but tasty, perfectly balanced, nice one.

Decent reddy-brown hue and not crystal clear, with a small but fine ivory head. The aromas woody, with some yeasty aroma like a Champagne, and a rich caramel or dark toffee. In the mouth its not too sweet, but burnt and dark sugars suggest sweetness. The clean, dry finish does it great favours and keeps it from being sickly. Could definitely session this. The body is rather flat, but perhaps they were aiming for the famous carbonation (or lack thereof) of British ales, so Ill allow it! Overall, though not my favourite style its pleasant and I could drink a few. I do find the sky-high score here on Ratebeer a little baffling though.

Aroma:

Medium aroma of malts, caramel, nuts, bread, roasted malts and coffee.

Appearance:

Turbid/opaque ruby/dark brown beer with heavy yeast and with a slight/medium beige head.

Taste/Palate:

Starts medium sweet with malts, caramel and nuts; ends slightly bitter and dry with roasted malts and coffee.

Overall:

This beer is rather intense, complex and balanced. Does everything that a brown ale needs to do. Funny that it says the beer only has 17 IBU, because it feels as more. The aroma could have been stronger, but that is the only flaw.

On tap at ale smith brewing. Pours out brown topped with a sand head. This beer is a bench mark nut brown for sure. Nose is tons of nuts wood rich malts and some sweetness. Taste is more of the nice rich nutty notes and wood.

650 ml, je crois. Belle noire à reflets rubis. Mousse à grosses bulles. Nez discret où pointent les fruits secs (chataîgne et évidemment noisette), le chocolat, ... Bouche : fruits noirs (prune), noisettes, pain, chocolat avec légère amertume. Pas trop de corps mais pas mal tout de même. Bue après une Port Brewing peut expliquer et naide pas forcement !
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer.

Opaque dark brown pour with ruby highlights and a beige head with decent retention. Spotty lacing. Light/thin mouthfeel for a brown. Definite nutty flavor. Slightly acidic finish. Liquid nuts. Kinda one-dimensional.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2017 Rami Rami is drinking a Nut Brown Ale by AleSmith Brewing Company at BrewDog WarszawaSa orzechy i karmel, mila faktura, ciut jakiejs ziolowosci, slodkawe, niezleOcena potraktowana skryptem do przeliczania ocen (uzgodnienie UT/RB).

Kolor:  Piękny mahoniowy kolor. Pod światło widać, że jest czyściutki, w 100%-ach klarowny. 
 Piana:  Niewielka, drobniuteńka, jasnokremowa.
Zaraz po nalaniu stacza się w dół do chmurki.
Na ściankach szkła pozostawia liczne krążki.
Może nie jest zbyt trwała, ale ładny lacing wynagradza resztę. 
 Zapach:  W aromacie mnóstwo nut słodowych.
Są herbatniki, są ciasteczka maślane i również te w typie brownie.
Jest lekkie kakao i trochę czekolady.
Najwięcej jednak odnajduje tutaj nut orzechow laskowych, co bardzo mnie cieszy, bo lubię ten klimat w piwie.
Aromat nie miażdży, nie jest jakiś wybitnie intensywny, ale jest na tyle przyjemny, żeby zauroczyć moje zmysły. 
 Smak:  Ach te orzechy! Czuje je wszędzie. Na języku brylują także nuty chlebowe, ciasteczkowe, ponownie brownie, ciemne muffinki z kosteczkami czekolady.
Jest też sproszkowane kakao i szczypta czekolady.
Faktura średnia, nie oleiste, ale też nie wodniste.
Kremowowe, jedwabiste odczucie w ustach.
Bardzo smaczne i wysoce pijalne piwo. 
 Wysycenie:  Średnie. 
 Podsumowanie:  

AleSmith Brewery z San Diego, California udowadnia tym piwem swoją klasę. Jest leciutkie, sesyjne, kremowe i aksamitne na języku. Pachnie nieźle, ale jeszcze lepiej smakuje.
Mamy tutaj klasyczne, słodowe Brown Ale w stylu angieslkim z wieloma akcentami.
Wilopłaszczyznowy profil budują: ciasteczka maślane, brownie, kakao, delikatna czakolada, BARDZO dużo orzechów laskowych, trochę chleba, muffinek czekoladowych.
Jest na prawdę pięknie!
To była uczta dla moich kubków smakowych.

Bottle from Whole Foods Market in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is strong roasted nuts, twigs, roasted malts, mild smoky malts, mild coffee. Taste is a mild tang (like a mild porter), dry roast malts. Solid.

Bottle. Dark brown with small foam ring. Aroma is nuts, chocolate, some bread and some roasted. Taste is nuts, some caramalt, some chocolate and some sour coffee (but not much). A nice balanced bitter ending.

Pours a dark brown, almost going into black. Medium small beige head on top of it. Rich malty nose with dark chocolate upfront, bicuits and some vanilla with a bit of bourbon in the finish. Later on a fine hazelnut develops. Taste follows with pleasant chocolate sweetness. Silky body with hints of bitterness. Creamy maltiness. Full body but lightly drinkable. A hint of warmth in the end. A slightl sparkly feel in aftertaste. A delight

Bottle from Bridgend Service Station. Ruby body with a thin off-white head. Very faint lacing. Aroma of toffee, earthy hops and stewed tea. Flavour of burnt caramel, flat Coca-Cola and cocoa powder. Thin to medium body with a watery, slightly oily texture. Light fizz. Beautifully balanced.

Bottle to glass - Color of root beer, thin wispy light beige head. Very rich aroma of roasted nuts, maple and coffee.... Notes of vanilla. Great smell. A tad underwhelming by comparison on the tongue. Some what standard brown. Caramel malts, roasted nuts. Earthy bitter finish. Par.
Dark Ruby brown with dissipating head. Delicious hazelnut aroma with a little vanilla and coffee bean. Nutty taste, sweet, lightly acidic. A little creamy but nothing like rogues.

This is, like, the Fabrege Egg of nut browns or something. And not just some knockoff that looks sparkly and pretty from a distance but lacks craftsmanship once you get up close and start poking around its details. Complex and bittersweet and the dry finish leaves you ready for another sip immediately.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2016 Pours a nice mahogany with minimal, quick-disappeared tan head. Aroma is amazing, fully realizing the nut component with hazelnuts dominating a malty roast. Flavor is similar though theres a weakness and slight acidity. Finish is somewhat dry.

EDIT: On second try with clean palate, the flavor matches my aroma description. Great stuff - maybe my new favorite of the style.

Good nut brown ale. Pours a little think with a hint of coffee and vanilla smell. The taste is clean and the beer is easy to drink! Not my favorite style but a well done variation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

0,355l from bottle at Isabella, Maribor. brown color, small tan head. smells of caramel, spices, earthy, light roasty, burned malts, some hints of herbal hops. nice smell. medium body, soft carbonation, slick mouthfeel. tastes light roasty, spices, dark fruits, bready, lightly earthy. finishes lightly earthy bitter with some dark fruits and spices. quite nice one, drinks quite good.

Bottle from Specs. Dark clear brownish reddish with a pillowy tan head and very light lacing. Aroma of vanilla, toast, nuts, earth and milk chocolate. Taste is toasty and dry and lightly bitter. Medium bodied.

12oz bottle, BOTTLED ON 02/11/16. Nose light roast and strong cocoa powder, nutty with bg red fruit. Pour is brown that still lets a lot of light through up even close to the tip, gradient somewhat to the bottom, where theres a lot of ruby and some amber seepage. Head short rocky tan. Only lightly crisp, lots of red berry that starts to sweeten up fast and resemble sliming clove, but the backed-off cocoa and light cola moments are pleasant, as is the faint woodiness and blacker malt. Low but very smooth bitterness, a great mix of malt and grain flavors, smooth on the whole and pretty quaffable. Medium body, clean and still fresh-tasting. Would be reaching a bit for me to call it classically British, but it is distinctly not in line with normal American browns, and theres interesting own character to boot. [2016.08.22: 3.7]

12 oz. bottle served in a shaker- poured a barely heavily brown with darkened maroon shading transparent when held to a light source. Dark tan ring about the glass for a head, nominal lacing. Aroma of toffee, bakers chocolate, and nuts. Hits the mouth with a medium body, malt is finely sweetened, middle has some firmness to it, finish has some nuts in it. Could drink this all day and not complain one bit.

dark brown with brown reflections still translucent ruby with bright, fine white foam. clean fresh aroma and robust roasted malts, nuts, vanilla or caramel accented by the nutty aroma of chocolate malt and fruity hops and fermentation. Soft chocolate flavor, roasted nuts and nut. The pleasant light sweetness in the mouth is balanced with a subtle bitterness that prevents the beer is cloying and with a slight dryness produced by the chocolate malt. Feeling very soft mouth, somewhat dry.
Shared 12 oz. bottle. Dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of roasted malt. Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, nuts, and coffee. Delicious.

Bottle from AEON liquors. Pours a clear brown with a finger of foam that dissipates fairly quickly. Toasted almond, cacao nib and toasted bread all come off the nose with a touch of grassy hops as it warms. More of the same on the palate, slightly sweet though. Finish is drier. Not bad but nothing special really.
Bottle a brown colored beer with a white head aroma malts citrus nuts fruits spicy dark fruits and hops flavor malts citrus fruits dark fruits nuts spicy and bitter hops
Cask at GBBF 2016. Clear copper, medium beige head. Nutty and caramelly malt aroma, floral hops. Medium bodied, low to medium carbonation. Semi dry, low to medium bitterness.
Bottle in wine glass. This is a real muddy one. Nutty and brown sure is a fair description.
Bottle. Roasted almond, wort malt, and hay aroma. Very dark brown with small head. Moderately sweet nutty chocolate malt and moderately bitter dry hay/ash flavor. Okay body.

330ml served in a pint glass. Pours a dark amber to nut brown color with lots of suspended particles inside. Forms a big and creamy beige head with medium retention that forms some small spotty lacings in the glass. Nose is sweet and roasted. Strong notes of toffee, chocolate, caramel malts and nuts. Grassy and resin hops style. Taste is slightly sweet, in overall. Strong notes of toffee, chocolate, caramel malts and nuts. Hints of grass and resin. Mild hops bitterness. Medium, creamy and very smooth body. Chocolate and nuts in the aftertaste. Good drinkability. An AleSmith never disappoints.

Aroma: very malty and rich; Appearance: dark amber with thin, white head and dissipates slowly; Taste: follows aroma with distinct but not overpowering nuttiness; Palate: medium body with creamy mouthfeel; medium, malty finish; Overall: quite good but not quite as good as other Alesmiths. Would still definitely buy again.
The aroma is nutty with malt and very little hops. The appearance is brown. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is smooth. Overall standard brown.

Very dark and nutty with a rich toffee flavor, not hoppy but warm and delicious 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle:
Clear, dark brown with strong red backlights and a puffy, light tan head.
Chocolate, peanut aroma.
Taste is mild.....chocolate covered peanut, chocolate malt.
Sweet with a soft roasty finish.
Very solid.

Bottle at home (bottled 03/06/15). Pours red brown with a large offwhite head. Lots of carbonation. Aroma of sweet light roasted malts, light chocolate, caramel, nutty, earthy. Taste is moderate sweet, light bitter, nutty, caramel, light roasted malts, light chocolate, earthy, dry ending, earthy nutty caramel malty aftertaste. Nice.

Schön röstig, nicht zu stark. 
Aroma sehr unangenehm, muffig, grüner Apfel.
Im Geschmack süß, Schokolade, Kaffee, Nuss mit viel Fantasie. 
Im Nachgeschmack erinnert es an Tiramisu.
bottle. Brown with one finger head. Medium body. Light chocolate malt, smooth with slight nutty notes. Some faint vegetal is the only negative. Solid, enjoyable brown ale.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a very small sized head of foamy light tan colored bubbles that were very quickly diminishing and left behind a semi-transparent light brown colored body and a poor lacing. The mild aroma was brown malt. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start mediumly tingly at the finish with a lingering nutty aftertaste. The nice flavor contained notes of nutty mild hops and brown malt. A decent one that I would consider drinking again.
Malty. Enjoyable. Easy to drink. Had at the brewpub in miramar. Light nuttiness without any roastiness

On tap at brewpub. A slightly hazy ruby reddish brown ale with a short lived white head. Aroma is hazelnut, caramel. Flavor is chocolate, caramel, hazelnut. Finish is loads of roast, coffee, light grass. Lngering roast and toasty. Light to medium body, sticky mouthfeel and average carbonation.
On tap at Hay Merchant. Pour is brown with a nice tan head. Aroma is toasty malts. Taste is decidedly nutty and toasty. Really good.

Bottle (from beergium). Pours dark brown with beige brownish head. The head stays for some time. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity, some citrus, some caramel, slighty nutty notes. Flavor is sweet and bitter, cocoa, malt, fruits, apples, some caramel, some nuts, slight alcohol. Finish is caramel sweetness with dry-cocoa bitter. Overall: very nice.

Over a one year old bottle. A dark brown beer, a head is very big and light brown. Aroma has nuts, herbs, some wood, dark bread and chocolate. Taste has nuts, herbs, bread and some sweetness of fruits. Only medium- bodied, the body could be stronger. High carbonation. The age isnt a problem. Pleasant beer, even the style is not my favourite. Fresh, nutty and slightly bready.
Draft. Pours a dark brown. Aroma and taste are caramel, chocolate, and biscuit.

Pours a light brown with a small short lived head. The aroma was fine though nothing special. I was disappointed in the color...and the flavor. I probably had my hopes up too high, expecting more. I will have to try this one again in the near future to assure myself I wasnt being a bit too harsh in this rating.
Pours a brown color with a foamy white head. Aroma is nut, caramel, cocoa, and earthy hops. Flavor is similar. Has a lively, light body. A little bit sweet, but finishes dry. This is excellent.

355ml bottle. Pours a clear brown with a small, short lived, beige head that laces. Sweet aroma of roasted malt, caramel and nuts. Sweet flavour of roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, bread and nuts with a dry finish. Medium body with a smooth, oily texture and soft carbonation. Nice.

Pours a translucent dark brown. Aroma is mostly coffee with a strong hint of cocoa. Flavor is more of the same. Mouthfeel is a tad thin, but considering the style, its right on. No head or lacing to speak of. Carbonation is perfectly light. If the mighty Brewers at Alesmith ramped up the Cocoa (and/or malt profile) this beer would be perfect. Another great one from Alesmith.
Nutty aroma with tones of cocoa. Pours dark brown with a thin, tan head. A very pleasant taste of nuts and milk chocolate with a nice bitterness. Creamy, with low carbonation. I like very much.
Bottle. Dark amber with a small tan head. Malty and nutty tones. malt, caramel, nuts and hops. Medium body with a nice malty / nutty finish.

Pours a dark mahogany color with a small tan head. Aroma is sweet and nutty with some mild cocoa notes. Taste is sweet hazelnut flavor, mild cocoa notes. dark malts and some mild roasted bitter hops. Palate is a medium rich creamy body with mild carbonation. Finish is sweet hazelnut flavors with some cocoa dark malt and mild roasted earthy hops bitterness for balance. Has a very rich and smooth malty background. Overall a very tasty and delicious brew. Very nice
Pours a nice mahogany color aromas cocoa, cinnamon, slightly roasty with flavors similar to the aromas plus some chocolate and caramel flavors as well very nice
red brown pour long lasting head. Aroma chocolate oats. Tastes smoke caramel. leather. sweet and complex. Creamly lightly acid perfect palate

Bottle. Pours a beautiful medium brown with garnet highlights and a off-tan ring head. Nose is chocolate, roast filberts, dates, cinnamon, nutmeg, and Boston brown bread. On the tongue, its astonishingly rich and complex; spice and smoke up front, then a myriad number of dark fruits and nuts followed by fresh wheat bread, a little hops bitterness, and dark chocolate. My first AleSmith beer, and damn, its a beauty.

Pours dark brown with heavy light-tan head. A strong chocolate malt aroma. A balanced flavor of chocolate, caramel, coffee, and light roasted malts. A creamy chocolate and light coffee and nut aftertaste.
12 oz bottle. Aroma is malty and nutty. Flavor is malty and caramel to begin with, jsut a little bit hoppy and bitter on the finish.

Draft 0.15l at The Beer Temple Amsterdam, The Netherlands. 24.05.2016. Taste with Zlotta. Pour it cloudy brown color with small white head. Aroma coffee beans, some caramel on the back. Taste starts with coffee, red fruits in the middle, quite yeasty and smooth texture, some nuts, molasis little bit and figs at the end. Average carboantion, medium body, bitter finish.

Bottle from Asahiya. Pours brown with mahogany highlights, almost no head, floating particles. Cocoa and coffee aroma, toffee and nuts. Earthy flavour, quite bright hop, cocoa, nutty malts. Low but lingering carbonation, medium body, very smooth finish, easy to gulp down. Im not much into brown ales, but this works well.

Pian niska, sycząca, szybko gaśnie praktycznie do zera. Barwa mahoniowa, klarowna. Aromat mało wyrazisty, głównie karmel i toffi, może w tle laskowe orzechy... W smaku półwytrawne, mdłe, mega karmelowe, znów w posmakach orzechy laskowe i to praktycznie tyle. Goryczki brak, wysycenie średnie, wodniste.
Raczej słabo jak na Top 50 piw z gatunku Brown Ale... Przede wszystkim piwo jednowymiarowe, puste, mało intensywne i nudne...
Dark bronze pour, thin tan head. Nose is nutty and malty. Bittersweet. Middle is light coffee, and medium mouth feel dark roasted malt. Finish is bittersweet and chocolaty. Good brown.
Brown color. Aroma of hazelnut, brown malt and some bitters. Simple taste of nuts, malt, bitter mild hop and some creamy choco. Not bad, just solid.
Pours a hazy brown with tiny floaters very thin tan head. Malty and nutty aroma. Malty and nutty flavor.

Aroma - roasted nuts, peanut shells, and caramel.
Appearance - the body is bistre brown, with fine sediment. The head is beige and around 1 1/2" and fades.
Taste - has roasted nuts, mild toast, cocoa, and some earthiness.
Palate - medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, and toasty

Sampled from tap at Beertemple. Clear, dark reddish brown with a tan head. Sweetish, roasty aroma of coffee, dark chocolate and toasted nuts. Sweetish-malty, moderately roasty taste of caramel, dark chocolate, coffee and toasted nuts, followed by a short, slightly roasty-bitter finish. Medium body, slightly creamy mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Quite nice!
On tap at Alesmith brewpub. Heavy great malty nutty rye aroma fresh black roasted coffee. Light malty crisp fresh bomb. So good roasted malt brown.

Bottle picked up locally from notes. Pours a clear dark amber brown color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have toasted malts, some sweetness, caramel, nutty, mild dark chocolate, earthy bitterness, good for what it is, but still a brown ale even from Alesmith.

Bottle, 355ml. Deep reddish with a frothy to minimal tan head. Aromas of roasted caramel, nuts, bitter chocolate, some fruity hints. Medium bodied with flat carbonation. Smooth, creamy and oily. Medium sweet with a slight sourness and low bitterness. Earthy malt character into a sourish and alcohol finish. Unusual but quite pleasant.

Bottle, 355ml. A dark reddish beer with a minimal white head. Aroma is of nuts, dried fruits and malt. Taste is moderately bitter with flat carbonation. Medium bodied, creamy and with a dried fruit aftertaste. Very easy to drink and very English-style.

12 fl oz bottle, bought in Mill Valley, CA. Dark red brown in the glass, a lot of small sediments in the glass. Small short living head. Malty on the nose. Taste starts also malty, increasing to the middle part, little bit toasted, with hopy elements until the aftertaste. Some sweetness. Okay and easy to drink.

Tap @ Beer Temple, small sample, thanks to the bartender. Clear deep amber to brown color. Aromas: nutty, red fruit, light caramel/butter. Retronasal the red fruit is more upfront, with light caramel and a hint of butter. Flavor is light sweet, fruity. Light bodied. Finishes light roasty, moderate bitter. Decent but not very exciting.
From tap at BeerTemple, Amsterdam. Aroma is malt, nuts, caramel, touch of coffee, some chocolate. Flavour is mildly sweet. Body is medium and a bit creamy. Very nice nutty Brown Ale.

Pours reddish-brown with a nearly non-existent head. Aroma is malty, with cocoa, nuts and a little bread. Slightly sweet chocolate malt, lightly bitter roasted flavor with a roasted, nutty aftertaste. Palate is smooth and modestly slick, medium to light body, soft carbonation.

Bottle into pint glass, hazy ruby brown color with tan head. Aroma notes of cocoa, hazelnut nuttiness, caramel , light dark malt and tad earthiness. Taste seems stronger than aroma notes; adds toffee and faint earthy bitterness. Light-medium body, moderate carbonation, tad creamy with simple roast finish. Very good brown ale.

Botella. @El Cabanón, Avilés 15/04/2016. Bottled:07/02/15
Color marrón, sabor malta, chocolate, cuerpo medio, rica y agradable de beber.

12 oz bottle poured, paired with game 7 of the season. Pours a thick, reddish (in the right light) color with a thin fizz head. Aroma consistent with the expected nutty malt. Flavor is cool, malty, soft almost chocolate like, but without the thick mouth feel. Clean tasting brown ale here. Quite the model for the style. Enjoyed this one.

Pours a mahogany color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma is nutty, bready malts. There is some sweetness in there as well. The mouth feel is creamy and there is a noticeable nuttiness and brown bread. World class but brown ale.
Bottle at tasting. Brown color. Aroma of hazelnut, brown malt and some bitters. Simple taste of nuts, malt, bitter mild hop and some creamy choco. Not bad, just solid.
A very good nut brown ale. Pours dark brown with copper highlights. Caramel and walnuts on the aroma. Rich, dense bready malt flavor with honey and caramel notes. Really tasty.
pour red brown with a fine white head. nutty aromas, with caramel and cocoa hints. taste light bitter notes, and a light sweetness. medium bodied. average carbonation, soft bitter finish.

Bomber. Aroma is nutty, cinnamon, bready, wet river rock, licorice. Pours brown but looks clear amber in the light; medium beige head with good retention and a little lace. Taste is sweet, roasty and nutty. Not bad, but Ive had better examples of the style.

Cant believe I hadnt tried this yet. A pure masterpiece in sessionable beers (created back before that was a buzzword). Aroma had me a little worried. Dark roasted malt, light chocolate and notes off toffee. A little thin. Pour was a nice deep dark brown with a thin tan film for a head. Taste was so much bigger and fuller than the aroma. First sip hit the tastebuds hard. Strong walnut, chewy toffee and roasted caramel were big and full- especially for the low ABV. Mild carbonation. Very nice beer
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Nice brown ale. Pours mahogany, mild nutty aroma. Smooth tasting, easy drinking.
Pretty generic. No hop aroma to speak of. The malt is missing. However, still pretty easy drinking and flavorful. Nothing wrong with this.
A solid brown ale, smooth, light malt, nice medium brown ale. March madness 2016.

Bottle. Bolime tasting.  Brown colour, light beige head. Aroma nit very significant. Some coffee, caramel, some nuts, a bit earthy hops. Taste caramel, roasted, some coffee, nuts, earthy hops. A bit yeast. Overcarbonated. Not bad, but nothing special.
Bottle at Bolime tasting 3/2016. Clear brown colour. High carbonation. Mostly malty and sweet. Caramel and light chocolate. Moderate pear fruity aroma and flavour.
Tasted at Bolime tasting. Dark brown colo with medium beige head. Coffee, roasted malt, coffee, nuts in aroma. Taste, coffee, caramel, nuts. Long coffee finish.
Bottle at Bolime tasting 3/2016. Pours brown color, lightly beige head. Aroma of caramel, nuts. Taste is medium sweet, lightly bitter, caramel, nuts, chocolate, bit overcarbonated.

Pours chestnut brown with an off white head that fades rapidly to tiny blinking bubbles. Aroma is roasted malt; nutty; toffee. Tangy and active on the palate. Flavors follow the aroma with nice rich chocolate malt, toffee, touch of fruit. Very smooth and flavorful. Excellent variation of this style.

Pours a darker amber in color with a medium, bubbly, off white head. Aroma contains roasted malts, nuts, caramel, some chocolate, and lesser bread. 12oz bottle. Hazy brown color with a white head. Sweet roasted malt aroma. Smooth medium body. Sweet roasted malt flavor toffee.

Bottled:Brown, somewhat hazy colour. Thick head. Earthy aroma with notes of chocolate, biscuits and fudge. Smooth and rounded mouth feel. Taste is chocolate, licorice, toffee and plums.

Medium brown in color with a creamy khaki colored head. Aroma is nutty, roasty, with notes of caramel and light chocolate. Really good body and silky going down. Lots of flavor and really easy to drink.

Bottle thanks to my wife stephrocks: Poured a caramel brown with tan head. Aroma is sweet malts. Taste is a mix of sweet and roasted malts.

Disclaimer: If you leave your rating book at an event there is a chance someone will write in it. Apparently I absolutely love this beer! Tastes like dem titties.

Bottle. Pours a clear amber brown with a tan head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a nice nuttiness with some sweet grains and a bit of a bread note. Flavor has a bit more bread with a nice nuttiness and a light sweetness supporting.
Poured from bottle. Very nice nutty and roasted malt aroma that follows through in the flavour. Very smooth.
Tap at Erzbierschof Zurich. Very nutty aroma indeed, beautiful. Creamy and malty, soft and pleasant, but still with a good dose of taste. Laid back and really well done.

Big bottle acquired by Wreck It Ralph host from Princeton Liquors. Served up in a large mug. Dark brown color. Little bit of roasted malt aroma with nut characteristics. Taste has some chocolate espresso notes. Sweetness at the onset. Lots of roasted notes. Surprisingly quite drinkable. Its mouthfeel is slightly thin...probably more than I expected. Getting a dose of bitterness at the end. Like dark chocolate bars. Nice beer overall.

Poured rom a bottle dated 23 Nov 2015. Pours a deep reddish brown with a thin tan ring. Medium body, clingy. Roasted malt and nut aroma. Smooth but somewhat flat tasting. Nut flavor is rather weak. Not sure if this is its normal flavor or just a bad bottle? It was not very good. Flat and blah, hard to enjoy it this way.
Bottle. Dark brown body with tan head. Aroma is malts nuts and dark caramel. Taste is malty with some leather and hints of tobacco. Aftertaste is malty sweetness nice balanced by some bitterness.

Bot, pour appears somewhat thick. Quite dark. Friendly roasted chocolate mild aroma. Quite friendly and reserved on the palate, enjoyable. Feels a little thick and slippery on the tongue, not much co2. Almost has a cask feel about it.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Brown color with reddish hues and beige head. Aroma has very nice nutty, chocolate and coffee notes. Smells delicious. Taste starts sweet and nutty but finishes quite watery and bland. Body is also on the light side with smooth carbonation. Aroma is great but the taste doesnt quite deliver.

Sampled on draft at 3R6P this beer poured a dark brown color with orange highlights and a small foamy off white head that left good lacing. The aroma was dry, roasty and woody. The flavor was dry, toasty, woody and earthy with a bot of cola. Medium length finish. Medium body. Ok.
On tap @ Alesmith new brewery location in Miramar. Medium brown, cooper highlights. Aroma is coffee and brown bread, flavours are the same, with a roasty bitter finish. Nice brown.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Dark brown body with a thin beige brown head. Aroma is malty, caramel and dark chocolate. Taste is sweet with medium biterness. Hoppy finish. Medium body, light carbonation.
Robust and slightly chalky malt aroma. Brown color with a small tan head. Mild sweet beginning with a light finish.
Drank during the tasting with my roommates 02-01-16. Neutral smell but the taste is quite rich for a beer with this ABV. Mouthy, spicy, nuts, pretty creamy and good body. Very drinkable.

Rating #1540 - 20.03.2015 - Birthday Brewery Tour - On tap at Alesmith - Dark brown pour with a weak bubbly tan foam that disappears quickly. Aroma is strong roast malts, hint of nutty sweetness. Medium-full bodied Taste is bold roasty, light sweetness, well hopped character, earth, spice, hazelnut with a slightly bitter finish that is quite pleasant. Superb.

Bottle from giant eagle new Albany. The ale poured a dark opaque brown color with a smallish head and no lacing. You are greeted with the aroma of roasted malts and cashew nuts. The taste has chocolate and nuts in a nice blend. The medium body ale has soft carbonation. This is a wonderful brown ale with a clean finish with roasted malt in the aftertaste

22 oz bottle. One of the twelve beers of Christmas 2015. The ale poured a dark opaque brown color with a smallish head and no lacing. You are greeted with the aroma of roasted malts and cashew nuts. The taste has chocolate and nuts in a nice blend. The medium body ale has soft carbonation. This is a wonderful brown ale with a clean finish with roasted malt in the aftertaste.
Rich bread crust, cocoa, roasted barley nose. Flavor is same plus mild toffee, delicate red apple esters.

Pours deep brown with minimal lacing. Aroma of carbonated vanilla coke and nuts. Slightly sweet, initially a bit more noticeable on the hops than I'd expect but mellows over time. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark brown body with a red hue. Burnt toffee nose. Nuts with more burnt toffee with a hint of chocolate on a smooth plate. Slight clean bitter finish.

Rated by BrewTom

Tap @ Mikkeller Bar Aarhus. Pours a dark reddish brown with a medium offwhite head. Aromas of malt, cocoa, dark fruits, chocolate, berries. Taste is cocoa, chocolate, malts, dark fruits, berries, ripe sweet red prunes, dry finish.

Aroma: nuts and roasted malt. 
Flavour: roasted malt with some fruits and nuts. 
Colour: dark reddish brown with a white head.

On tap at Mikkeller bar Aarhus. Pours a deep, dark, reddish amber with a small off White head. Aroma has lots of toasted malts, nuts, slight caramel, very fruity, berries. Taste is Fairly sweet, a dry toast, Nice Dark malts and a slight hoppy/bitter roasted finish. Nice and smooth, average carbonation.

22 oz bottle shared by ebone1988. The pour is a dark brown with a lovely garnet color showing through. There is a large off white head that falls to a nice film with a decent amount of soapy lace. The aroma is pretty good. There is a nice nuttiness that hides a light malt. It's pretty basic, but all browns are. A light caramel comes in on the back end, but it's basic, yet good. The flavor is a lot smokier than I was expecting, and I don't like it. There is a nice nuttiness and a good caramel malt to accompany it. It's light, but good. The mouth feel is light and crisp like you'd want it to be. The carbonation is at a good level, and the aftertaste is nutty and good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared with koleminer20. Aroma is nutty, slightly metallic, sweet malt, good. Appearance is brown, light tan head. Taste is nutty, a bit of smoke, roasted malt, maybe some coffee, very good. Mouthfeel is medium body, medium/soft carbonation, great aftertaste. Overall, this is pretty tasty.
12oz bottle. Pours brown with a tan head. Spot on for the style. Sweet but not too sweet caramel and nut flavors with a nice earthy notes. Not my favorite style but they certainly nail it here.
On tap. Flavor is thick and malty with light roasted notes. Not a lot of nuttiness really. Slightly creamy finish. Slightly sweet. Not bad, but not exceptional.
Bottle. Toasted caramel, cocoa and coffee aroma. Initial taste has a fair amount of bite and it has a bitter chocolate aftertaste. OK beer overall.

Roasted nuts, bread crust, and toast aroma, decent strength. Clear brown, medium tan head, low retention. Pecan, wood, soil. Light to medium body. Balanced, even slightly to the dry side, very sessionable, but flavorful.

Bomber. Turners, Sheffield. Clear, deep bronze. Halo of tan head. Nutty malts. Cocoa. Some cake fruits. Taste is vine fruit sweet. Light, woody bitterness. Thin body, to the point of being watery. Finishes thin and vaguely bitter.

Bomber. Chestnut brown pour, generous off-white head with exceptional retention and lace. Nose is malty, pumpernickel, dark roast, some hints of diacetyl and caramel. Mouth is medium bodied, lightly bittersweet, cocoa, coffee, hazelnuts, butterscotch, toasted bread. Solid.

A deep brown pour with a medium to thin fizzy head that gives you a good idea of the mouthfeel (runny, carbonation on the moderate side). Aroma is candied peanuts, cocoa, Vollkornbrot, toffee-ish dark malts, and the most subdued earthy hops. Taste defined by low bitterness that segues into a sweet, gentle finish, with fading flavors of milk chocolate, brown bread, nuts, caramel, and earth. Lots of taste for such a sessionable beer, and a notch beyond other standard brown ales.
At domion wine and beer it is poured from a bottle and is a Dark brown color with a thin beige head. The Aroma is malty, caramel and the Taste is sweet with a hints of coffee thin finish

Shared bombers poured to wine glasses for sampling at the Binnys of Glen Ellyn, IL. California Love Tasting. Showed a clear, brownish gold color, with a frothy layer of light tan head foam, and spots of lacing. The nose was toasted, nutty, and woody, with touches of bakers cocoa, and caramel. Light to medium bodied, with decent effervescence, the taste added an earthy bitterness, and finished crisply dry. A tasty, no nonsense Brown Ale.

This was poured into a pint glass.
The appearance was a dark ruddy brown color with a one finger off white foamy head that dissipated within about a minute and a half but even after dissipation it still left a nice looking concave to valley-like looking cap of a wake of a head. Lacing moderately streamed itself around the glass.
The smell started with some sweet and roasty nuts and entered into some nice light cocoa and coffee bitterness.
The taste was moderately sweet through the nuts and the cocoa allowing to blend into the full flavor. Theres a slight lingering semi-sweet to roasty maltiness running into the aftertaste and finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a really nice sessionability about it. Carbonation runs pretty light.
Overall, as an English-styled brown ale, Alesmith did exactly what they wanted to with this one.

Backlog rating. Keg at BD Shoreditch, London. It pours a clean copper color with medium tan head. Aroma is medium sweet and lightly dry and hoppy, with some biscuit, bread, dried leaves, sugar syrup, earth. Taste has some earth, dried leaves, light spice, pine cones. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, nice brown ale

Pours a rich, dark, mahogany with a creamy off-white head. Generous lacing. Nose is malt and biscuit with caramel notes. Taste is balanced. Nice, creamy malts and a hoppy finish. Medium body, effervescent carbonation. Very nice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark brown body with a thin beige brown head. Aroma is malty, caramel and dark chocolate. Taste is sweet with medium biterness. Hoppy finish. Medium body, light carbonation.
Bottle. Reddish brown colour. Toffee caramel aroma. Medium body, caramel flavour, some sweetness
Bottle from cervezalandia. Dark brown to red color. Medium beige head. Medium body. Sweetness is medium. Medium bitterness. Flavour is light fruit, liquorice, nutty, light coffee, cacao, bread.

22 oz bottle purchased at 7-11 Kittery. Deep brown in color with light thin head with minimal lacing. Aroma show light chocolate, roasted nuts and English ale yeast.

The flavor is about average for the style. Nuts, sweet malts, chocolate, toffee with a very mild hop presence in the back end. Mouthfeel is pretty good ( a tad fuller for a Brown) plus side of medium. How awesome can you really make a brown ale? Ale Smith does a good job with the style guideline and certainly nothing wrong with this but... Its just a brown ale. Good and drinkable ( I wonder what some of the variants are like?)

bottle @ Jungle Jims / Eastgate OH --- Clear mahogany brown color, Over-anxious four finger beige head that is slow to recede, heavy lace cobwebs. Taste is solid malt that becomes sweeter as it hits a medium carbonated swallow, adding nuts and chocolate before a lightly hopped finish. Well-balanced and complex. Huge brew for a 5% abv. Recommended.
650ml bottle. Brown color with light beige head. Malty aroma, caramel, bread, some dusty coffee notes, light fruity. Sweet and bitter taste. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.
Pours a mahogany color with a creamy off white head. Notes of roasted nuts, milk chocolate, earth hops, toffee, and cocoa crispies. Medium weight mouthfeel.

Bottle at Studenterbaren. Dark brown body. Fruity aroma. Medium sweet taste with light bitterness. A bit on the thin side. Medium body with very fizzy carbonation. I had higher expectations for this simply because it comes from AleSmith. The carbonation almost ruined it for me - whenever I had a sip, it all turned to foam in my mouth. Not very drinkable.
Roasted, nutty, easy drinking; decent color and appearance. A good representation of the style and distinctive in its own way. (at 2015 Summer Beer Dabbler, St. Paul, MN)

Aromas a nuez, caramelo, en menor proporción malta tostada y ligeramente frutos rojos. 

Cuerpo redondo, color café con destellos rojizos, carbonatacion media y corona de espuma media con ligera retención. 

En boca nuez, caramelo y malta.

Al paladar se integran bien los sabores de la nuez y el caramelo, se percibe maltosa y las notas tostadas se detectan en el retrogusto. 

En general una buena cerveza, no empalagosa y fácil de beber
Bomber->dimpled mug. Dark brown with huge frothy beige head. A: heavy nuts and malts, bread. T: roasted malt, nuts, caramel, cereal. Some lingering bitterness. Decent.

Probably the most impressive to me of Alesmiths standard IPA, XPA, ESB, and Nut Brown lineup. Really well executed use of malts to get a complex balance of grains, roastiness, biscuit, bread, faint chocolate, nuttiness, etc., that is exceedingly easy to drink but also has a good heft to it.

Bottled Mar. 2014. Supposedly doesnt improve with age, but doesnt feel like it degraded either. Great aroma: caramel, nuts (yes!), toffee, hints of coffee. Light, but not watery. Velvety mouthfeel. Moderate lingering bitterness, just enough. Very good, will be a new benchmark for the style for me.

Bottle at The London Craft Beer Festival. Pours a clear chestnut brown colour with a fizzy tan head. Aroma of toasty malts, nuts, caramel, slight vanilla, subtle toffee, and some spicy, earthy hops. Taste of toasty, roasted malts, nuts, caramel, some vanilla fudge and slight earthy hops. Medium bodied and moderate carbonation. A bittersweet, toffee, nut, slight earthy hop bitterness in the finish. Such a smooth, malty beer with a nice earthy bitterness to balance it out. The best American brown ale Ive had so far.
22oz Bottle. Poured a dark brown color. Lots of roasted, nutty notes. Light chocolate, silky notes. Pretty solid brown ale.

22 oz. bottle. Pours brown dark mahogany with a tight soapy khaki head that fades to a wispy film and collar. Aroma has nuts burnt sugar and roasted malt soft coffee. Taste is soft bitterness roasted malt day old coffee and burnt roasted nuts.

655 ml flaske. Klar mahognifarget kropp med et lavt lysebrunt skum. Mørk karamell tydeligst i duften, men også hint av tørt løv. God toastet maltsødme, litt bitter sjokoalde og et hint av syrlighet. Hint av røstede toner i ettersmaken. Medium fylde. Denne hadde tålt lagringen godt med tanke på at den ble flasket 22 februar 2013.
Dark brown. Color. Lacing head. Lots of malt, medium roast. Xry, cereals and grain. Some nuts. Thick palate. Some unroasted coffee.

Hazelnut and chestnut with a backdrop of bready caramel. Just the right amount of sweetness in a lightly carbonated body with a thin head. Probably noble hops - not a lot of sharpness coming from them - per the style of beer. What works particularly well here is the subtle sweetness with the stale notes that sometimes linger in this style.
From tap at CBC 2015. Dark brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, caramel, dried fruit, nuts and some bitterness.

1st May 2015CBC Red Session. Keg. Cloudy deep amber beer, small pale cream colour head. Palate is light and semi dry with mild fine carbonation. Light caramel malts, mild dried fruits. Modest pine hops. Dry finish. Not too bad.
On tap at CBC15. Dark brown with off white head. Aroma is malty, bready, light roasted, nuts and light yeast. Taste is similar, nutty, bread, biscuit, roasted malt and yeast.
Bottle; pours brown with a tan head; aroma is malty with some caramel and light nut notes; taste is roasted malt with nuts, caramel, and a hint of chocolate; finish is smooth with a touch of hops

4oz on tap at Brass Tap - U Square. Nice chocolate, nuttiness up front; some maple. Medium-plus body. Smooth, kind of soft, lighter carbonation. Balanced finish, neither dry nor slick. Light to moderate sweet taste, nice light bitterness. No lingering sweet syrupiness. Clear brown amber color. Thin off-white head, leaving decent lace. Overall, a very solid nut brown ale. Met my high expectations for Alesmith, unlike the Robust Porter I recently tried from them (it was just OK).

Draught @ Ginger Man. Brown with a reddish tint, large creamy beige head, cocoa and hazelnut aroma, low carbonation, bitter roasted malt taste with hazelnut, thin body, medium bitter finish. Smooth and drinkable, though a bit watery.
Tap at CBC 2015, Copenhagen. Originally rated 20150502. Colour is clear brown with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Nuts, chocolate and roastiness.

@red cbc 2015
fruity, sweet, well balance. maybe a pale ale more than a brown ale
Tap @CBC15. Clear copper, small, bubbly light beige head. Roasted aroma with notes of coffe and chocolate. Strong roastedness, coffee hints.
UPDATED: JAN 9, 2016 Bottle from Beergium. Deep red-brown color, with beige head. Roasted malt and caramel nose, earthy. Nutty taste, hints of chocolate and yeast. Medium body.

Pours a half finger of light tan head on a clear brown body.
The aroma is faint caramel and roasted malt.
The taste is cream, nuts,mild chocolate milk and a little pine bitterness to round it out.
The texture is smooth and soft.
Pretty tasty.

On tap at brewdog in January during tap takeover. Dark brown pour with quite a stable chestnut colour head. Aroma is roasted malts, nuts and yeast. Reasonable taste
 Yeast, malts etc but a little stale. Ill have this again from a bottle and rerate.

Bottle 65cl, a dark beer with medium head and good retention. Nose is on chocolate, dark coffee, nutty. Aroma is on dark malt, dark chocolate, toasted nuts, roasted coffee, medium creamy body, light roasted nuts. Quite complex for the alcohol level. dry roasted notes on finish.

Couleur ambrée sombre, très légère mousse beige. Super nez malt noir, chocolat, café en grain, noisette grillée. Gout malté grillé, boisé et noisette grillée, avec note de chocolat et houblon avec petite amertume. Bon Corps. Fin de bouche légère amère grillée. Simple mais nickel pour 5c°
21.12.2014. Ruby brown. Aroma of malts, caramel, nuts. Flavour is smooth and slightly bitter, malts, dark fruits. Hoppier brown ale.

Bottle. Beautiful looking beer, not particularly aromatic. Rich malts, but not too sweet due to a balanced hop presence. Less intense than the Samuel Smith, for instance. Dont taste any alcohol. Very drinkable.

[2/19/15] Draught at Alesmith in San Diego. Reddish brown color. Pleasant malty aroma of toast, nuts and a bit of caramel. Sweetish flavor, malty, toasty and nutty, with a drier note. Rounded mouthfeel. Nice stuff.
Dark brown pour with a creamy off-white head. Aroma of nuts, roasted malt, and caramel. Chocolate, caramel flavor with roasted malt, and nuts. Very nice beer!

Some nut, some caramel. Tastes like macadamia. Pours maroon with good head and lacing. Very drinkable, this stuff would be great by the pitcher. Light sweet finish with hint of roast. Tap at Gingerman NY.
Bottle, 650 ml from Whole Foods Bowery, New York. Pours brown with tan head. Roasted malts and nuts aroma. Roasted malts, chocolate, nuts, hint of hops. Bitterish end.

Bottle gift from SJ. Ale Smith does everything right once again. Bold notes roasted malts, Earth tones, hop with a dry chocolate finish. Decent body, great brew. Excellent representation of the style.

Bottled 650ml. -from Svijet Piva Zagreb. Brown coloured with a red glare, medium sized pale brown head, mild nutty caramel nose. Light roasted malt, caramel, dark chocolate and light nutty with touch of hops in the finish. Pleasant one.

Deep brown body with a quite large, tan head that ends up as a thin layer. Very good lacing. Malty, sweet and strong aroma of dark caramel, nougat and chocolate, backed up by some gentle hoppy notes. Strong flavour that follows the aroma, with some additional vague citric hints. Light to moderate sweet and moderate bitter taste. Light-bodied, pretty dry and with a bit watery mouthfeel. One of the better brown ales Ive had. 
[65 cl bottle, enjoyed 2 years after bottling, from Vinmonopolet Vika, Oslo]

Tap. Pours deep clear mahogany, medium creamy tan head, nice lacing. Aroma is light, nutty, bready, roasted malt. Flavor is light plus sweet, light bitter, nutty, dark breads, touch of toffee. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel.
A little chocolate and a little freshly baked bread in the aroma, slightly sweet taste and a shade of dryness on the finish. Great weight and an overall delight. From a bomber.

Chocolate, nuts and roasted malt in the aroma. The roasted malt and chocolate really does taste enjoyable to the fullest. Exquisite bitterness that fills the mouth for a long while. Really a good beer as quickly drink up. Luckily it was on big bottle. Follow me @ Kung av öl @ Facebook for more pictures and ratings.
UPDATED: JAN 23, 2015 Clear crimson, strong beige head. Chocolate, toffee and nuts on the nose. Very smooth, sweet but not overly so. Nuts and toffee, finishes on a bitter note. Very nice.

On tap at 83° in Carlsbad, CA. 

Clear, very dark mahogany with a khaki head and good lacing. 

Very nutty aroma of hazelnuts, chestnuts, chocolate and roasted malt. 

Equally nutty taste of hazelnuts, chestnuts, peanuts, roasted malt, cocoa, bitter orange, rusty metal and a touch of tartness. 

Medium body and medium carbonation. 

I was disappointed by this over-the-top nutty beer. Beyond a certain level of intensity, the nuts add an astringency and do not se m to blend well with the other bitter flavors in this beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Keg at Brewdog Brum. Proficient yes, but couldnt Professor Profile this one. Sweet, cakey. Certainly nutty - like caramelised hazelnut topping on a krispy kreme donut. A bit sickly maybe.
Tap at Brewdog Glasgow. Aroma is lightly spicy and nutty! Bit of chocolate. Easy drinking. Malty. Nice.

Bottle from Brewdog.

Nutty smell, nutty taste, sweet malts, chesnuts, touch of dark chocolate and a wee bit of coffee, some fruityness in there too.

Keg at Brewdog. Dark brown, small white head. Aroma is musty with some coffee. Body is medium, quite foamy, lowish carbonation. Taste is big rounded malt, slightly sour-ish, coffee vibe, jammy raspberry, old ale. Good.
Burnt coffee, milk chocolate, moderate hops. Notably sour. Bitterness and sourness out of balance with richness from malts.
Pours a dark mahogany with a creamy head. Slight nut aroma, taste is quite sweet, caramel? Think the keg might be too cold.

English inspired brown ale with sticky, pale beige, stable head and dark wine red colour, clear. Aroma of cocoa powder, nutmeg, iron, dried leaves, peanuts, dried orange peel, maple syrup, cane sugar, vanilla, candied figs, roasted chestnuts, cigarette tobacco and a faint, strange, sourishly sulphuric and sweaty hint of Sauerkraut, but not too disturbing. Dried fruits open the taste profile, on a nutty and caramelly malt base, restrainedly sweetish, a bit more spicy in the end (retronasally, I get a vague hint of that nutmeg flavour again) with a leafy and slightly citrusy hop bitterness of medium strenght and length; thinnish body. Ending is primarily soft nutty and caramelly malts. English brown ales were never my favorite style and as much as I came to admire this brewery, this is my least prefered AleSmith beer so far - though I hasten to add that in this particular style, this is surely a more than decent example.
